Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r it might not be easy for you to use, but if you are trying to track down when something broke, `git bisect` is the way to go

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: and ths bug existed BEFORE it

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: starting to affect lots of random things... we have 1 node that is repeatedly doing it .. so thats a good start

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: for `git bisect`, you write a shell script that returns true or false, and that defines "good" and "bad" and then `git bisect` can use Newtons Bisection method to cut down the search space in half, repeatedly, to find a commit that "breaks something"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so you need something deterministic to check for

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: https://git-scm.com/docs/git-bisect

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it can really be a life saver, to track down when something broke. If you can write a deterministic test for it (which isn't always easy)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: what do you mean by that?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: no masternodes are needed by coins that add DPoW

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: KMD DPoW is not *completely* distributed, there are 64 elected notary nodes which other nodes trust to not be evil. Some coins/communities have a problem with this.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am one of those 64 (I actually run it as a team with another person), so maybe you should not trust what I say

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: for examples of external coins that added DPoW: EMC2, GAME, HUSH. None of them have masternodes

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: LTC, BTC and ZEC fork, respectively

Author: enver#0753
Content: Have to read more about how the notarienodes work than...    i see   , i got something  wrong before

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @enver notary nodes are a service KMD provides

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you don't have to run one. I think I could make that clear in my docs, a few people have that confusion

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you could become a notary node in the future, if you want. That election happens in Q1/Q2 each year

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's a lot of work, and in reward, notaries earn 75% of the KMD block reward

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but just to add DPoW, you just use the service that notaries provide

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: which are "notarizations"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: which you can think of as embedding the blockhash of your coin into KMD, which then goes into BTC

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's proof of the correct block hash. even a 51% attack will not be able to make nodes go off the correct chain, even when it's a minority

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```Chapter 13 - Different Languages
The current codebase is integrated into the komodod codebase, which is C/C++. However, it is possible to use different languages and integrate into the C/C++ as zcash has shown by using the rust language for some parts of the zcashd.

I think any language that is compiled and can create a linkable library while being able to call and be called by C/C++ functions can be used. If you are able to make such a language binding for a simple CC contract like faucet, this will be good for a 777 KMD bounty. Of course, you need to be the first to submit a properly working pull request.

```
